question: Which painting style is regarded as the first school of Pahari paintings in Jammu & Kashmir?
The Mankot style of paintings began to favour <u>subdued colours and naturalism</u> during which century?
Artist Nainsukh was patronised by which ruler of Jasrota?
The distinguishing trait of the Kashmiri Qalam miniature paintings is their evocative depiction of ______.
The earliest surviving examples of Kashmiri paintings come from which place, dating to about the 8th century AD?
Which Kashmiri ruler invited artisans from Persia and Iran, revolutionising local arts & crafts?
Under Mughal patronage, especially that of Emperor _____, Kashmiri artists developed their own style.
Pahari miniature painting styles emerged primarily between which centuries?
Pashmina shawl fibre is chiefly obtained from the Kel goat, native to which region?
Why is a traditional Ring shawl so named?
options: It is woven in circular looms
It can pass smoothly through a small ring

question: The trade in Shahtoosh shawls is banned internationally because it involves killing which endangered species?
A genuine Kani shawl may take up to how long to complete, depending on complexity?
The term Phulkari in embroidery literally translates to what?
In Kashmiri handicrafts, Jalakdozi is another name for which technique?
Unlike chain-stitch textiles, crewels are typically worked using ____ yarns on a white base.
Which highly delicate embroidery on Pashmina shawls can take <u>years</u> to finish a single piece?
Tilla work involves embroidering with which materials?
The carpet industry of Kashmir valley was first introduced by which ruler?
In local terminology, hand-knotted Kashmiri carpets are popularly called ______.
The Khabdan pile carpets of Ladakh typically employ about \(48\) knots per square inch on a ______ loom.
Recycling old woollen blankets to create colourful Gabba rugs is centred mainly in which district?
Compared with carpets, Namda felted rugs are generally ______.
Papier-mâché craft reached Kashmir through artisans invited from ______ by Sultan Zain-ul-Abidin.
Traditional papier-mâché objects are finally coated with varnish after decoration using three categories of colours: mineral, organic, and ______.
The most iconic item of Kandkari copperware is the _____, a kettle used for making kahwa.
A Kanger is essentially a/an ______ lined wicker basket filled with hot embers for winter warmth.
Walnut trees suitable for Kashmir’s famous wood-carving grow at elevations of roughly ______ ft.
Which Kashmiri willow-based craft uses plant stalks and shoots woven into utilitarian objects like baskets and lampshades?
Samba district is renowned for calico block printing that traditionally employed vegetable dyes such as ______.
Special <u>Sonhri</u> and <u>Rupehri</u> prints once used real leaves of which metals?
The intricate ceiling craft Khatam Band primarily employs which wood?
Speakers of the Dogri language are collectively known as ______.
Dogri became an official language of Jammu & Kashmir through the 2020 bill passed on ______ 2020.
Historically, Dogri was written in Dogri Akkhar, a script akin to _____.
Urdu replaced Persian as the state language of Jammu & Kashmir in which year?
Kashmiri belongs to the <u>Dardic</u> subgroup of the Indo-Aryan family and is officially written in the ______ script.
Approximately how many Gojri speakers reside in Jammu & Kashmir?
Balti, spoken in Nubra valley, is considered an archaic form of which major language?
Another name for the Ladakhi language is ______.
The Jammu & Kashmir Official Languages Bill expanded the official list to five languages; which of the following was already official before 2020?
Kalhana’s celebrated \(\textit{Rajatarangini}\) chronicle was originally composed in which language?
Mystic poetess Lal Ded composed her spiritual verses known as ______.
Who is credited with translating the Quran into Kashmiri?
The lyric form Loal was introduced into Kashmiri poetry by which Nightingale of Kashmir?
Mahmud Gami’s celebrated Kashmiri masnavi <u>Yusuf Zulaikha</u> exemplifies influence from which classical language’s poetic form?
Kashmiri poet Rasool Mir is often compared to which English Romantic poet?
Who earned the title Shayar-e-Kashmir for inspiring nationalist fervour through poetry?
Dina Nath Nadim’s opera <u>Bombur Taa Yambarzal</u> (Bumblebee & Narcissus) is notable as Kashmir’s ______.
Abdur Rehman Rahi became the first Kashmiri recipient of the Jnanpith Award in which year?
The novel Dod Dag, regarded as the first in Kashmiri, was authored by ______.
Scholar Tashi Rabgias compiled over 200 traditional songs in which Himalayan region?
The village of Chilling is famed for producing ritual vessels from alloys such as ______.
In Ladakh, a Tsug-dul woollen rug is primarily used as a ______.
Which fibre combination is common in Tsug-gdan rugs used along Ladakhi kitchen walls?
Shahtoosh is often called the <u>“King of Wool”</u> because of its extreme ______.
Mulberry silk produced in Jammu & Kashmir is considered among the ______ quality in Asia.
Sarees embellished with Soznikari are prized chiefly for their ______.
The two main types of Gabba rugs are Yerma and ______.
Large selections of Namda rugs can most readily be found in emporiums located in ______.
Chain stitch embroidery in Kashmir is popularly performed with a hooked needle known as _____ .
The Kangra school of painting bears closest stylistic resemblance to which Jammu style?
Painter Nainsukh employed the hybrid Persian technique called ______ in court scenes.
In Pahari art, bold lines, blazing colours, beetle-wing embellishments, and geometrical design are hallmarks of the ______ series painted in 1664 AD.
The Jammu & Kashmir Academy of Art, Culture & Languages was set up in 1958 and declared autonomous in ______.
Mystic poetess Rupa Bhawani wrote in Kashmiri yet was proficient in both Sanskrit and ______.
Arinimal and Habba Khatoon are revered as the ____ of Kashmiri women’s lyric tradition.
Traditional motifs such as the <u>chinar leaf</u> are especially prevalent in Kashmiri ______ work.
The prolonged soaking of paper before pulping is a critical step in Kashmir’s ____ craft.
Walnut wood carving was introduced to Kashmir during the reign of which 15th-century ruler?
Fateh Kadal locality is especially known for producing engraved ____ vessels.
Chinese and Mongolian aesthetics influenced the design repertoire of Ladakh’s ______ carpets.
Material combinations of sheep wool, yak wool and goat hair are typical in Ladakhi ____ rugs.
The Gabba industry is concentrated in Anantnag, while the Namda industry centers on which city?
A Kashmiri wicker shopping basket is woven after willow twigs are first cleaned and cut into strips about ______ mm wide.
In historical Kashmir, the Sharada script was primarily utilised after the ______ century AD.
The Ladakhi bridal ornament Sondus (or Branshil) is worn on which shoulder?
Abhinavagupta’s Tantrasara (c. 1015 AD) represents early use of Kashmiri language within commentaries on which philosophical school?
Kani shawls are woven using needles traditionally fashioned from which material?
The Ring shawl test demonstrates chiefly the ______ of its Pashmina weave.
Which embroidery type is especially reserved for Kashmiri bridal trousers?
In Sozni work, the needle creates minute stitches that often cover only the ______ surface of the shawl.
The dogri language was first mentioned in the writings of which medieval poet-scholar?
Punjabi spoken in Jammu region is generally written in which script within India?
UNESCO lists Bhaderwahi under which status?
The Kashmiri language was made a compulsory subject in all secondary schools from ____ 2008.
The first ever Ladakh Literature Festival was organised in Leh in which month of 2019?
Jammu & Kashmir’s handicraft sector is considered the economic backbone after which primary sector?
Common vegetable, mineral and organic pigments are applied to papier-mâché items before finishing with ______.
In Khatam Band, intricate wooden panels are assembled without ______.
Nighat Sahiba received the Sahitya Akademi Yuva Puraskar in 2017 for her poetry collection titled ______.
The Progressive Writers’ Association in Kashmir had Abdur Rehman Rahi serve as its ______.
Chain stitch rugs created from assorted cut-outs of old woollens are popularly backed with ______ cloth.
Neem Kalam technique merges local aesthetics with miniature conventions imported from which empire?
The decorative copper kettle known as a samovar in Kashmir traces its etymological origins to which foreign language?
Kel goats producing fine Pashmina fibre are typically herded at altitudes above ______ m.
Which Kashmiri poet received the first Sahitya Akademi award for Kashmiri literature in 1956?
Sovereign craftsman titles like Gara in Ladakh refer primarily to occupational experts in ______.
The musical instrument chang pot produced in Ladakh is traditionally made out of which metal?
‘Ring clothes can pass through a ring.’ This popular test refers to shawls woven chiefly from which yarn?
Which Jammu craft integrates bamboo from the Shiwalik range into items like lamps and fruit bowls?
The Ladakhi dialect Lehskat is predominantly spoken in areas around ______ town.
Sharada, Perso-Arabic and Devanagari collectively serve as orthographies for which language?
George Grierson remarked that Kashmiri is the only Dardic language possessing what feature?
The Rasamanjari series was painted by artist Devidasa under patronage of which ruler?
The silver–embellished head ornament Chaunk Phool is traditionally worn by women of which Jammu district?
Which Kashmiri painting genre experienced decline after the 11th century due to loss of patronage?
‘Voice of the Himalayas’ – an annual magazine in English & Bhoti – was published by which Ladakhi scholar?
Kashmiri papier-mâché artisans sometimes reinforce items with brass linings primarily to ______.
The distinctive Khawa beverage prepared in samovars is flavoured chiefly with ______.
Which embroidery is <u>not</u> typically practised by Kashmiri artisans?
The Kashmir Silk saree often features intricate Kashida work executed on which base material?
What is the local term for the warming pot that Kashmiris carry under their cloaks in winter?
Which Pahari language group is spoken in the south-eastern parts of Jammu & Kashmir?
The Guler–Jasrota school flourished primarily during which centuries?
Which embroidery uses hooks rather than needles to execute looping stitches?
Kashmir’s papier-mâché artisans categorize their pigments into mineral, organic and vegetable; ‘vegetable’ implies colours derived from ______.
The Neem Kalam technique literally translates to ______ pen.
Large shikaras and houseboats on Dal Lake showcase panels decorated using which woodcraft?
Traditional Kashmiri jewellery often incorporates stones like turquoise, coral and ______.
Gabba rugs called Yerma are distinguished from Dal Guldar primarily by their ______.
Which city hosts the headquarters of the Jammu & Kashmir Academy of Art, Culture & Languages?
The Purgi language is chiefly spoken by which ethnic group in Kargil?
In Kashmiri crewel work, vibrant colours are generally ______.
Which award did poet Dina Nath Nadim receive in 1971 recognising his contribution to literature?
Akhtar Mohiuddin refused the civilian honour of Padma Shri in protest over the ______.
The economic relevance of handicrafts in Jammu & Kashmir is heightened due to the region’s ______ winters.
What colour leaf motif is quintessential in Sozni borders depicting Kashmir’s iconic tree?
The Perso-Arabic variant used for Kashmiri employs additional diacritics to represent ____ specific sounds.
Aari embroidery on rugs often depicts hunting scenes and stylised animals influenced by which Central Asian art?
